source.name: City of Adelaide / Which Bin SA
source.notes: Based on official City of Adelaide and Which Bin SA guidelines. Yellow-lid bin for recycling, fortnightly collection. Container Deposit Scheme (10c refund) for eligible containers.

materials.name: Aluminium foil
instructions: Scrunch into a ball at least the size of your fist
notes: Adelaide accepts aluminium foil if scrunched to fist size
Small pieces fall through sorting — scrunch together into a ball
commonMistakes: Don't put flat or small pieces of foil in — scrunch to at least fist size
Don't include foil-lined chip packets or wrappers — those go in general waste

materials.name: Aluminium drink cans
notes: Eligible for 10c refund via Container Deposit Scheme — consider returning instead
Don't crush — keep shape for sorting
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans — sorting machines need the shape
Don't include cans with liquid still in them

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
notes: All metal food cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them — rinse first
Push loose metal lids inside the can for safety

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Remove plastic lid — lids go in general waste
notes: Adelaide accepts empty aerosol cans in the yellow-lid bin
Do not puncture or crush
commonMistakes: Must be completely empty
Don't include if still pressurised
Remove plastic overcap

materials.name: Drink cartons and UHT cartons
notes: Adelaide accepts Tetra Pak and gable-top cartons
Includes juice boxes, long-life milk, soup/broth cartons
commonMistakes: Don't flatten — leave 3-dimensional for sorting

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: Place loose in yellow-lid bin — must be whole and unbroken
notes: All colours of glass accepted
Many glass bottles eligible for 10c Container Deposit refund
Must be unbroken — broken glass goes in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in general waste
Remove metal or plastic lids

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: Labels can stay on
Lids should be removed
commonMistakes: Don't include broken jars — wrap and place in general waste
Don't include ceramic containers, Pyrex, or drinking glasses

materials.name: Newspaper
notes: Do not bag in plastic — items must be loose
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic
Don't include heavily soiled or wet newspaper

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: Window envelopes accepted — no need to remove plastic window
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels, tissues, or napkins
Don't include shredded paper — it goes in general waste in Adelaide

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Place loose in yellow-lid bin or beside it on collection day
notes: Large boxes should be flattened and cut down to fit
Can be placed beside the yellow-lid bin if too large
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food — that goes in green-lid bin
Flatten to save space

materials.name: Cereal boxes and boxboard
notes: Thin cardboard / boxboard accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic bags and liners inside
Don't include waxed or foil-lined boxboard

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper accepted
Staples OK to leave in
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Junk mail and flyers
notes: Accepted as paper
commonMistakes: Don't include if laminated or plastic-coated

materials.name: Envelopes
notes: Small plastic windows are fine
commonMistakes: Don't include padded envelopes with bubble wrap lining — those go in general waste

materials.name: Plastic drink bottles
instructions: Remove the lid — lids go in general waste
Place bottle loose in yellow-lid bin
notes: Rigid plastic containers accepted — numbered plastics #1-7
Many bottles eligible for 10c Container Deposit refund
Remove lids
commonMistakes: Remove the lid before placing in the bin
Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic milk bottles
instructions: Remove lid — lids go in general waste
notes: Accepted as rigid plastic container
commonMistakes: Remove the lid
Rinse out milk residue

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles
notes: Accepted as rigid plastic container
commonMistakes: Remove trigger spray tops — they go in general waste
Don't include if heavily contaminated

materials.name: Rigid plastic meat trays
notes: Only RIGID plastic trays accepted — not foam/polystyrene trays
Must be clean
commonMistakes: Don't include foam/polystyrene trays — those go in general waste
Remove the absorbent soaker pad

materials.name: Yoghurt tubs and dairy containers
instructions: Remove lid — lids go in general waste
notes: Rigid plastic dairy containers accepted
commonMistakes: Remove foil or plastic lids
Rinse out dairy residue

materials.name: Ice cream containers
notes: Rigid plastic ice cream containers accepted
commonMistakes: Must be clean — rinse out residue
Remove the lid

materials.name: Plastic takeaway containers
notes: Rigid plastic takeaway and produce containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include foam containers — those go in general waste
Rinse to remove food residue

materials.name: Shampoo and personal care bottles
instructions: Remove pump/lid — goes in general waste
notes: Accepted as rigid plastic container
commonMistakes: Remove pump tops
Squeeze out remaining product

materials.name: Soft plastics and plastic bags
instructions: Some supermarkets have REDcycle drop-off bins
notes: Soft plastics are NOT accepted in Adelaide's yellow-lid bin
If you can scrunch it into a ball, it's soft plastic
REDcycle at Coles and Woolworths (check availability)
commonMistakes: Never put soft plastics in the yellow-lid bin — they tangle sorting machinery
Never bag your recycling in plastic bags

materials.name: Polystyrene and foam
notes: Not accepted in Adelaide's yellow-lid bin
Includes foam food trays, cups, and packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put foam trays in the yellow-lid bin even if they have a recycling symbol
Don't include packing peanuts in recycling

materials.name: Broken glassware and crockery
notes: Broken glass contaminates recycling
Only whole, unbroken glass bottles and jars go in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put broken glass in the yellow-lid bin
Wrap sharp edges to protect waste collectors

materials.name: Ceramics and crockery
notes: Ceramics cannot be recycled with container glass
Different melting point contaminates glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses and glassware
notes: Different glass composition to bottles — contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Window glass and mirrors
notes: Treated glass — different composition to container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Nappies
instructions: Bag and place in general waste (dark-lid) bin
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green-lid bin
Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Tissues and paper towels
notes: Too contaminated for paper recycling
Clean paper towels can go in the green-lid bin with food
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Shredded paper
notes: Adelaide specifically does NOT accept shredded paper in the yellow-lid bin
Too small for sorting — falls through screens and contaminates other materials
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Recycling in bags
instructions: NEVER bag your recycling — all items must be placed LOOSE in the yellow-lid bin
If recycling is bagged, the entire bag goes to landfill
notes: Bagged recycling cannot be sorted and is treated as contamination
This is a very common mistake in Adelaide
commonMistakes: Never put recyclables inside a plastic bag
Tip items out loose into the yellow-lid bin
examples: Recyclables stuffed in a plastic bag
Tied bag of bottles and cans

materials.name: Plastic straws and cutlery
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
SA has banned single-use plastics — switch to reusable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Food wrappers and snack packets
notes: Metallised plastic film cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Cling wrap and glad wrap
notes: Soft plastic — not accepted in yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Plastic lids also go in general waste
notes: NOT recyclable — the plastic lining prevents recycling
Many Adelaide cafés offer discounts for reusable cups
commonMistakes: Don't put coffee cups in the yellow-lid bin
The lid is also not recyclable

materials.name: Light bulbs (incandescent and LED)
notes: CFL and fluorescent tubes are hazardous — take to a drop-off point
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin
Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which need special disposal

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in general waste (dark-lid) bin
notes: Not accepted in the green-lid organics bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green-lid bin

materials.name: Damaged clothing and shoes (non-donatable)
notes: Only truly damaged, non-donatable items go in general waste
commonMistakes: Donate if still usable — don't throw away wearable clothing

materials.name: Greasy pizza boxes
instructions: Tear off clean portions and recycle in yellow-lid bin
Or place in green-lid organics bin if your council accepts food-soiled cardboard
notes: Grease contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put the whole greasy box in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Thermal receipts
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA — contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Food scraps (general)
instructions: Use a kitchen caddy with compostable liner to collect scraps
notes: Adelaide green-lid bin accepts all food waste including meat, dairy, and cooked food
Green-lid bin collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — only certified compostable liners
Don't put food in general waste if you have green-lid bin service

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Remove fruit stickers and rubber bands

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper to reduce odour
notes: Adelaide's industrial composting handles meat and bones
Includes raw and cooked meat, poultry, fish, and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put in general waste if you have green-lid service
Wrap in newspaper, not plastic

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
notes: Paper tea bags break down well in composting
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-mesh or nylon tea bags

materials.name: Eggshells
notes: Crush for faster breakdown
commonMistakes: No need to wash

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Recycle the container separately in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put the container in the green-lid bin — only the food waste

materials.name: Garden waste
instructions: Large branches: cut to fit or take to waste transfer station
notes: Green-lid bin accepts garden organics alongside food
commonMistakes: Don't include soil, rocks, or treated timber
Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Grass clippings and leaves
notes: Green and dry leaves both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic — place loose in the bin

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
notes: Food-contaminated paper goes in green-lid, not yellow-lid
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Certified compostable bin liners
instructions: Use Australian Standard AS 4736 certified compostable bags only
Place filled liner in green-lid organics bin
notes: Only bags with the Australian seedling logo are accepted
Regular plastic bags labelled 'biodegradable' are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — even ones marked 'degradable'
Must be AS 4736 certified with the seedling logo

materials.name: Cut flowers
instructions: Remove plastic wrapping, ribbons, and ties
Place flowers in green-lid organics bin
notes: Green waste accepted in the organics bin
commonMistakes: Remove all plastic, ribbon, and wire first
Don't include the vase

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a battery drop-off point (Officeworks, Battery World, Aldi stores)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Batteries cause fires in trucks — NEVER put in any kerbside bin
B-cycle program for free battery recycling at major retailers
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in any kerbside bin
Tape terminals to prevent short circuits

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Paintback drop-off point
Bunnings and other hardware stores participate in Paintback
notes: Paintback is a free national paint recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a participating workshop or council waste depot
notes: Used oil can be re-refined
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or on ground

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to a Household Hazardous Waste collection event or depot
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Gas bottles and cylinders
instructions: Take to a gas supplier or waste depot
Never put in any kerbside bin
notes: Pressurised containers are explosion risks in waste trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL bulbs
instructions: Take to a participating retailer (Bunnings) or waste depot
notes: FluoroCycle program — free drop-off at Bunnings
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't break them — mercury is hazardous

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Return to any pharmacy — RUM (Return Unwanted Medicines) program
Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications for free
notes: RUM Project is a free national program
Call 1300 137 118 for guidance
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to an e-waste drop-off event or waste transfer station
notes: E-waste contains valuable recoverable materials
SA has regular e-waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Wipe personal data first

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to charity shops (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross, Good Sammies)
notes: Adelaide has many charity bins and op shops
Only donate clean, dry items in good condition
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't donate wet or heavily soiled items

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Check your council for hard waste collection
Or take to a waste transfer station
Some scrap metal dealers accept for free
notes: Many Adelaide councils offer annual or on-request hard waste collection
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Remove doors from fridges for safety

materials.name: Tyres
instructions: Take to a tyre retailer or waste depot
Most tyre shops accept old tyres when you buy new ones
notes: Tyres are banned from landfill
Tyre Stewardship Australia program
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Container Deposit Scheme (10c refund)
instructions: Take eligible containers to a collection depot or reverse vending machine
Eligible containers have a 10c refund mark
Find your nearest depot at cdssa.sa.gov.au
notes: SA pioneered container deposit in Australia
Most aluminium cans, glass bottles, plastic bottles, and cartons between 150ml–3L are eligible
Refund is 10 cents per container
Wine bottles, plain milk containers, and juice over 1L are NOT eligible
commonMistakes: Not all containers are eligible — look for the 10c mark
Don't crush containers — barcode needed for scanning

recycle: Aluminium foil — scrunched to at least fist size
Cartons — drink cartons, UHT/long-life, juice boxes
Glass bottles and jars — whole, unbroken, lids removed
Paper and cardboard — newspaper, office paper, magazines, cardboard, boxboard
Rigid plastic containers — bottles, tubs, trays, punnets (numbered plastics #1-7), lids removed
Tins, cans, and aerosol cans — empty, lids removed
compost: All food scraps — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Coffee grounds, paper tea bags, paper filters
Garden waste — prunings, weeds, grass clippings, leaves, cut flowers
Food-soiled paper (napkins, paper towels, paper plates)
Certified compostable bin liners (AS 4736 seedling logo only)
trash: Soft plastics, plastic bags, cling wrap, bubble wrap
Broken glassware, ceramics, crockery, drinking glasses

compost: Regular plastic bags (even if labelled biodegradable)

tips: Yellow-lid recycling bin is collected fortnightly — check your collection day
All items must be clean, empty, dry, and placed LOOSE in the bin — never bag recyclables
Remove container lids before recycling — lids go in general waste
Scrunch aluminium foil to at least fist size before placing in yellow-lid bin
Use Which Bin (whichbin.sa.gov.au) to look up any item — or call 1300 137 118
SA's Container Deposit Scheme gives 10c refund for eligible containers (cdssa.sa.gov.au)
Green-lid organics bin accepts all food waste plus garden waste — collected weekly
Only use AS 4736 certified compostable liners (seedling logo) in the green-lid bin
Adelaide has three bins: yellow-lid (recycling), green-lid (organics), dark-lid (general waste)
If in doubt, check whichbin.sa.gov.au or put it in the general waste bin to avoid contamination

locations.name: Container Deposit Scheme Depots
locations.notes: 10c refund per eligible container. SA pioneered container deposit in Australia. Multiple depots and reverse vending machines across Adelaide.

locations.name: Bunnings (various locations)
locations.notes: Free drop-off for CFL/fluorescent tubes and paint. Multiple Adelaide locations.

locations.name: Charity Clothing Bins (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross)
locations.notes: Located throughout Adelaide metro area. Only donate clean, dry items in wearable condition.

locations.name: Waste Transfer Stations
locations.notes: Check your council website for your nearest waste transfer station and accepted items.
